_**The Shape of Water**_ is a 2017 American [romantic](/wiki/Romantic
"Romantic") [dark fantasy](/wiki/Dark_fantasy "Dark fantasy")
[drama](/wiki/Drama_film "Drama film") film directed by [Guillermo del
Toro](/wiki/Guillermo_del_Toro "Guillermo del Toro") and written by del Toro
and [Vanessa Taylor](/wiki/Vanessa_Taylor "Vanessa Taylor").[3][4] It stars
[Sally Hawkins](/wiki/Sally_Hawkins "Sally Hawkins"), [Michael
Shannon](/wiki/Michael_Shannon "Michael Shannon"), [Richard
Jenkins](/wiki/Richard_Jenkins "Richard Jenkins"), [Doug
Jones](/wiki/Doug_Jones_\(actor\) "Doug Jones \(actor\)"), [Michael
Stuhlbarg](/wiki/Michael_Stuhlbarg "Michael Stuhlbarg"), and [Octavia
Spencer](/wiki/Octavia_Spencer "Octavia Spencer"). Set in
[Baltimore](/wiki/Baltimore "Baltimore") in 1962, the story follows a mute
[custodian](/wiki/Janitor "Janitor") at a high-security government laboratory
who falls in love with a captured [humanoid](/wiki/Humanoid "Humanoid")
[amphibian](/wiki/Amphibian "Amphibian") creature.

_The Shape of Water_ was screened in the main competition section of the [74th
Venice International Film
Festival](/wiki/74th_Venice_International_Film_Festival "74th Venice
International Film Festival"), where it premiered on August 31, 2017,[5] and
was awarded the [Golden Lion](/wiki/Golden_Lion "Golden Lion") for best film
in the competition.[6] It also screened at the [2017 Toronto International
Film Festival](/wiki/2017_Toronto_International_Film_Festival "2017 Toronto
International Film Festival").[7] It began a [limited
release](/wiki/Limited_release "Limited release") in two theaters in [New York
City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City") on December 1, 2017, before
expanding following December 8, 2017, and has grossed $194 million worldwide.
A novelization by del Toro and [Daniel Kraus](/wiki/Daniel_Kraus_\(author\)
"Daniel Kraus \(author\)") was published on March 6, 2018.[8]

_The Shape of Water_ received critical acclaim for its performances,
screenplay, direction, visuals, production design, and musical score, with
many critics calling it del Toro's best work since _[Pan's
Labyrinth](/wiki/Pan%27s_Labyrinth "Pan's Labyrinth")_;[9] the [American Film
Institute](/wiki/American_Film_Institute "American Film Institute") selected
it as one of the [top 10 films of the
year](/wiki/American_Film_Institute_Awards_2017 "American Film Institute
Awards 2017").[10] The film received a number of awards and nominations,
including thirteen nominations at the [90th Academy
Awards](/wiki/90th_Academy_Awards "90th Academy Awards"), where it won for
[Best Picture](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Picture "Academy Award for Best
Picture"), [Best Director](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Director "Academy
Award for Best Director"), [Best Production
Design](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Production_Design "Academy Award for Best
Production Design") and [Best Original
Score](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Original_Score "Academy Award for Best
Original Score").[11][12] It was nominated for seven awards at the [75th
Golden Globe Awards](/wiki/75th_Golden_Globe_Awards "75th Golden Globe
Awards"), winning for [Best
Director](/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award_for_Best_Director "Golden Globe Award for
Best Director") and [Best Original
Score](/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award_for_Best_Original_Score "Golden Globe Award
for Best Original Score").[13] At the [71st British Academy Film
Awards](/wiki/71st_British_Academy_Film_Awards "71st British Academy Film
Awards"), it received twelve nominations and won three awards, including [Best
Director](/wiki/BAFTA_Award_for_Best_Direction "BAFTA Award for Best
Direction").[14] The film also earned fourteen nominations at the [23rd
Critics' Choice Awards](/wiki/23rd_Critics%27_Choice_Awards "23rd Critics'
Choice Awards") and won four awards, including [Best
Picture](/wiki/Critics%27_Choice_Movie_Award_for_Best_Picture "Critics' Choice
Movie Award for Best Picture") and [Best
Director](/wiki/Critics%27_Choice_Movie_Award_for_Best_Director "Critics'
Choice Movie Award for Best Director").

## Plot[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Shape_of_Water&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Plot")]

Elisa Esposito, who was found in a river as an orphaned child with wounds on
her neck, is [mute](/wiki/Muteness "Muteness"), and communicates through sign
language. She lives alone in an apartment above a cinema, and works as a
cleaning woman at a secret government laboratory in
[Baltimore](/wiki/Baltimore "Baltimore") at the height of the [Cold
War](/wiki/Cold_War "Cold War"). Her friends are her [closeted](/wiki/Closeted
"Closeted") next-door neighbor Giles, a struggling advertising illustrator who
shares a strong bond with her, and her African-American co-worker Zelda, a
woman who also serves as her interpreter at work.

The facility receives a mysterious creature captured from a South American
river by Colonel Richard Strickland, who is in charge of the project to study
it. Curious about the creature, Elisa discovers it is a humanoid amphibian.
She begins visiting him in secret, and the two form a close bond.

Seeking to exploit the creature to American advantage in the [Space
Race](/wiki/Space_Race "Space Race"), General Frank Hoyt orders Strickland to
[vivisect](/wiki/Vivisection "Vivisection") it. One scientist, Robert
Hoffstetler—who is in truth a [Soviet](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union") spy
named Dimitri Mosenkov—pleads unsuccessfully to keep the creature alive for
further study and, at the same time, is ordered by his Soviet handlers to
euthanize the creature. When Elisa learns of the Americans' plans for the
creature, she persuades Giles to help her free him. Mosenkov discovers Elisa's
plot and chooses to help her. Though initially reluctant, Zelda becomes
involved in the escape, and it is successful.

Elisa keeps the creature in her bathtub, adding salt to the water to keep him
alive. She plans to release the creature into a nearby canal when it will be
opened to the ocean in several days' time. As part of his efforts to recover
the creature, Strickland interrogates Elisa and Zelda, but the failure of his
advances toward Elisa hampers his judgment, and he dismisses them. Back at the
apartment, Giles discovers the creature devouring one of his cats, Pandora.
Startled, the creature slashes Giles's arm and rushes out of the apartment.
The creature gets as far as the cinema downstairs before Elisa finds him and
returns him to her apartment. The creature touches Giles on his balding head
and his wounded arm; the next morning, Giles discovers his hair has begun
growing back and the wounds on his arm have healed. Elisa and the creature
soon become romantically involved, having sex in her bathroom, which she at
one point fills completely with water.

Hoyt gives Strickland an ultimatum, asking him to recover the creature within
36 hours. Meanwhile, Mosenkov is told by his handlers that he will be
extracted in two days. As the planned release date approaches, the creature's
health starts deteriorating. Mosenkov leaves to rendezvous with his handlers,
with Strickland tailing him. At the rendezvous, Mosenkov is shot by one of his
handlers, but Strickland shoots the handlers dead and then tortures Mosenkov
for information. Mosenkov implicates Elisa and Zelda before dying from his
wounds. Strickland then threatens Zelda in her home, causing her terrified
husband to reveal that Elisa had been keeping the creature. Strickland
searches Elisa's apartment and finds a calendar note revealing when and where
she plans to release him.

At the canal, Elisa and Giles bid farewell to the creature, but Strickland
arrives and attacks them all. Strickland knocks Giles down and shoots the
creature and Elisa, who both appear to die. However, the creature heals
himself and slashes Strickland's throat, killing him. As police arrive on the
scene with Zelda, the creature takes Elisa and jumps into the canal, where,
deep under water, he heals her. When he applies his healing touch to the scars
on her neck, they open to reveal [gills](/wiki/Gill "Gill") like his. In a
closing voice-over narration, Giles conveys his belief that Elisa lived
"happily ever after" with the creature.

## Cast[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Shape_of_Water&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Cast")]

  * [Sally Hawkins](/wiki/Sally_Hawkins "Sally Hawkins") as Elisa Esposito, a [mute](/wiki/Muteness "Muteness") cleaner who works at a secret government laboratory.
  * [Michael Shannon](/wiki/Michael_Shannon "Michael Shannon") as Richard Strickland, a [United States Colonel](/wiki/Colonel_\(United_States\) "Colonel \(United States\)") in charge of the project to study the "asset".
  * [Richard Jenkins](/wiki/Richard_Jenkins "Richard Jenkins") as Giles, Elisa's neighbor and close friend who is a struggling advertising [illustrator](/wiki/Illustrator "Illustrator").
  * [Octavia Spencer](/wiki/Octavia_Spencer "Octavia Spencer") as Zelda Delilah Fuller, Elisa's African-American co-worker and friend who serves as her [interpreter](/wiki/Interpreter "Interpreter").
  * [Michael Stuhlbarg](/wiki/Michael_Stuhlbarg "Michael Stuhlbarg") as Robert Hoffstetler / Dimitri Mosenkov, a Soviet spy working as a scientist studying the creature under an alias.
  * [Doug Jones](/wiki/Doug_Jones_\(actor\) "Doug Jones \(actor\)") as "Amphibian Man", an amphibious creature referred to as the "asset", with whom Elisa forms a close bond.
  * [David Hewlett](/wiki/David_Hewlett "David Hewlett") as Fleming, the laboratory's head of security.
  * [Nick Searcy](/wiki/Nick_Searcy "Nick Searcy") as Frank Hoyt, a [United States General](/wiki/General_\(United_States\) "General \(United States\)") who is Strickland's superior.
  * Stewart Arnott as Bernard, Giles' employer and former lover.
  * [Nigel Bennett](/wiki/Nigel_Bennett "Nigel Bennett") as Mihalkov, Mosenkov's handler.
  * [Lauren Lee Smith](/wiki/Lauren_Lee_Smith "Lauren Lee Smith") as Elaine Strickland, Strickland's wife.
  * Martin Roach as Brewster Fuller, Zelda's husband.
  * Allegra Fulton as Yolanda, a cleaning woman at the laboratory.
  * [John Kapelos](/wiki/John_Kapelos "John Kapelos") as Mr. Arzoumanian, the owner of the cinema who resided below Elisa and Giles' apartments.
  * [Morgan Kelly](/wiki/Morgan_Kelly "Morgan Kelly") as Pie Guy, a diner employee to whom Giles is attracted.

Production[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Shape_of_Water&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Production")]

[![\[icon\]](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/20px-
Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg)| **This
section needs expansion**. You can help by [adding to
it](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=The_Shape_of_Water&action=edit&section=).
_(March 2018)_  
---|---  
  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Still_from_the_Creature_from_the_Black_Lagoon_%2815666911261%29.jpg/220px-
Still_from_the_Creature_from_the_Black_Lagoon_%2815666911261%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Still_from_the_Creature_from_the_Black_Lagoon_\(15666911261\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Still_from_the_Creature_from_the_Black_Lagoon_\(15666911261\).jpg
"Enlarge")

The [Gill-man](/wiki/Gill-man "Gill-man") in _[Creature from the Black
Lagoon](/wiki/Creature_from_the_Black_Lagoon "Creature from the Black
Lagoon")_ was an inspiration to del Toro's concept.

The idea for _The Shape of Water_ formed during del Toro's breakfast with
Daniel Kraus in 2011, with whom he later co-wrote the novel
_[Trollhunters](/wiki/Trollhunters "Trollhunters")_.[15] It shows similarities
to the 2015 short film _The Space Between Us_.[16] It was also primarily
inspired by del Toro's childhood memories of seeing _[Creature from the Black
Lagoon](/wiki/Creature_from_the_Black_Lagoon "Creature from the Black
Lagoon")_ and wanting to see the [Gill-man](/wiki/Gill-man "Gill-man") and Kay
Lawrence (played by [Julie Adams](/wiki/Julie_Adams "Julie Adams")) succeed in
their romance.[17] When del Toro was in talks with
[Universal](/wiki/Universal_Pictures "Universal Pictures") to direct a remake
of _Creature from the Black Lagoon_ , he tried pitching a version focused more
on the creature's perspective, where the Creature ended up together with the
female lead, but the studio executives rejected the concept.[18]

Del Toro set the film during the 1960s Cold War era to counteract today's
heightened tensions, specifying, "if I say once upon a time in 1962, it
becomes a fairy tale for troubled times. People can lower their guard a little
bit more and listen to the story and listen to the characters and talk about
the issues, rather than the circumstances of the issues."[19]

Filming began on August 15, 2016, in [Toronto](/wiki/Toronto "Toronto") and
[Hamilton, Ontario](/wiki/Hamilton,_Ontario "Hamilton,
Ontario"),[20][21][22][23][24] and wrapped on November 6, 2016.[25]

In an interview with [IndieWire](/wiki/IndieWire "IndieWire") about the film,
del Toro said, "This movie is a healing movie for me. ... For nine movies I
rephrased the fears of my childhood, the dreams of my childhood, and this is
the first time I speak as an adult, about something that worries me as an
adult. I speak about trust, otherness, sex, love, where we're going. These are
not concerns that I had when I was nine or seven."[26]

## Release[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Shape_of_Water&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Release")]

_The Shape of Water_ premiered on August 31, 2017 at the [74th Venice
International Film Festival](/wiki/74th_Venice_International_Film_Festival
"74th Venice International Film Festival").[5] It also screened at [Telluride
Film Festival](/wiki/Telluride_Film_Festival "Telluride Film Festival"), the
[2017 Toronto International Film
Festival](/wiki/2017_Toronto_International_Film_Festival "2017 Toronto
International Film Festival") and [BFI London Film
Festival](/wiki/BFI_London_Film_Festival "BFI London Film Festival"), among
others.[1] The film was released in two theaters in [New York
City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City") on December 1, 2017 and then
expended to several other cities the following week. It had its official wide
release in the United States on December 22, 2017.[28]

### Home
media[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Shape_of_Water&action=edit&section=7 "Edit
section: Home media")]

On March 13, 2018, the film was released on [Blu-ray](/wiki/Blu-ray "Blu-
ray"), [DVD](/wiki/DVD "DVD") and digital download.[29]

##
Reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Shape_of_Water&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Reception")]

### Box
office[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Shape_of_Water&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Box office")]

As of April 17,
2018[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=The_Shape_of_Water&action=edit),
_The Shape of Water_ has grossed $63.8 million in the United States and
Canada, and $130.1 million in other countries, for a total of $193.9
million.[3]

After grossing $4.6 million over three weeks of limited release, the film
began its wide release on December 22, 2017, alongside the openings of
_[Downsizing](/wiki/Downsizing_\(film\) "Downsizing \(film\)")_ , _[Pitch
Perfect 3](/wiki/Pitch_Perfect_3 "Pitch Perfect 3")_ and _[Father
Figures](/wiki/Father_Figures "Father Figures")_ , and the wide expansion of
_[Darkest Hour](/wiki/Darkest_Hour_\(film\) "Darkest Hour \(film\)")_ , and
grossed $3 million from 726 theaters over the weekend, and $4.4 million over
the four-day Christmas frame.[30] The following weekend, the film made $3.5
million.[31] The weekend of January 27, 2018, following the announcement of
the film's 13 Oscar nominations, the film was added to over 1,000 theaters
(for a total of 1,854) and made $5.9 million (an increase of 171% over the
previous week's $2.2 million), finishing 8th.[32] The weekend of March 9–11,
following its four Oscar wins, the film made $2.4 million. It marked a 64%
increase from the previous week's $1.5 million and was similar to the $2.5
million made by the previous year's Best Picture winner,
_[Moonlight](/wiki/Moonlight_\(2016_film\) "Moonlight \(2016 film\)")_.[33]

### Critical
response[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Shape_of_Water&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Critical response")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/MJK35133_Sally_Hawkins_%28Maudie%2C_Berlinale_2017%29.jpg/220px-
MJK35133_Sally_Hawkins_%28Maudie%2C_Berlinale_2017%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:MJK35133_Sally_Hawkins_\(Maudie,_Berlinale_2017\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:MJK35133_Sally_Hawkins_\(Maudie,_Berlinale_2017\).jpg "Enlarge")

[Sally Hawkins](/wiki/Sally_Hawkins "Sally Hawkins")' performance garnered
widespread critical acclaim and earned her a nomination for the [Academy Award
for Best Actress](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Actress "Academy Award for Best
Actress").

On the [review aggregator](/wiki/Review_aggregator "Review aggregator")
website [Rotten Tomatoes](/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes "Rotten Tomatoes"), the film
has an approval rating of 92% based on 348 reviews, with an [average
rating](/wiki/Weighted_arithmetic_mean "Weighted arithmetic mean") of 8.4/10.
The website's critical consensus reads: "_The Shape of Water_ finds Guillermo
del Toro at his visually distinctive best—and matched by an emotionally
absorbing story brought to life by a stellar Sally Hawkins performance."[34]
On [Metacritic](/wiki/Metacritic "Metacritic"), the film has a weighted
average score of 87 out of 100, based on 53 critics, indicating "universal
acclaim".[35] According to [CinemaScore](/wiki/CinemaScore "CinemaScore"),
audience members under the age of 40 gave the film an average grade of either
"A+" or "A", while those over 40 gave it an "A" or "A−", on an A+ to F
scale;[36] [PostTrak](/wiki/PostTrak "PostTrak") reported filmgoers gave the
film an overall positive score of 80%.[37]

Ben Croll of [IndieWire](/wiki/IndieWire "IndieWire") gave the film an 'A'
rating and called it "one of del Toro's most stunningly successful works...
also a powerful vision of a creative master feeling totally, joyously
free."[38] Writing for _[Rolling Stone](/wiki/Rolling_Stone "Rolling Stone")_
, [Peter Travers](/wiki/Peter_Travers "Peter Travers") gave the film 3.5 out
of 4 stars, praising Hawkins's performance, the cinematography and del Toro's
direction, and saying: "Even as the film plunges into torment and tragedy, the
core relationship between these two unlikely lovers holds us in thrall. Del
Toro is a world-class film artist. There's no sense trying to analyze how he
does it."[39] For the _[Minnesota Daily](/wiki/Minnesota_Daily "Minnesota
Daily")_ , Haley Bennett reacted positively, writing, "_The Shape of Water_
has tenderness uncommon to del Toro films. ... While _The Shape of Water_
isn't groundbreaking, it is elegant and mesmerizing."[19]

Conversely, [Rex Reed](/wiki/Rex_Reed "Rex Reed") of the _[New York
Observer](/wiki/New_York_Observer "New York Observer")_ gave the film 1 out of
4 stars and calling it "a loopy, lunkheaded load of drivel" and, referring to
Hawkins's role in _[Maudie](/wiki/Maudie_\(film\) "Maudie \(film\)")_ ,
described people with disabilities as "defective creatures."[40] Reed's review
was criticized for referring to Sally Hawkins' mute character as "mentally
handicapped" and for erroneously crediting actor [Benicio del
Toro](/wiki/Benicio_del_Toro "Benicio del Toro") as the film's director.[41]

### Top-ten
lists[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Shape_of_Water&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Top-ten lists")]

###
Accolades[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Shape_of_Water&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Accolades")]

See also: [List of accolades received by The Shape of
Water](/wiki/List_of_accolades_received_by_The_Shape_of_Water "List of
accolades received by The Shape of Water")

_The Shape of Water_ received 13 nominations at the [90th Academy
Awards](/wiki/90th_Academy_Awards "90th Academy Awards"), the most of any film
in the 2018 race. It won in four categories: [Best Production
Design](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Production_Design "Academy Award for Best
Production Design"), [Best Original
Score](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Original_Score "Academy Award for Best
Original Score"), [Best Director](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Director
"Academy Award for Best Director"), and [Best
Picture](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Picture "Academy Award for Best
Picture").

The film also spawned some debate about whether the fact that it was filmed in
Canada, with a predominantly Canadian crew and many Canadian actors in the
supporting roles, should have made it eligible to be nominated for the
[Canadian Screen Awards](/wiki/Canadian_Screen_Awards "Canadian Screen
Awards"). Under [Academy of Canadian Cinema and
Television](/wiki/Academy_of_Canadian_Cinema_and_Television "Academy of
Canadian Cinema and Television") rules, to qualify for CSA nominations under
the rules for international coproductions at least 15 per cent of a film's
funding must come from a Canadian film studio. Even the film's Canadian co-
producer, [J. Miles Dale](/wiki/J._Miles_Dale "J. Miles Dale"), stated that he
supports the rules and does not believe the film should have been
eligible.[43]

### Lawsuit alleging
plagiarism[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Shape_of_Water&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Lawsuit alleging plagiarism")]

In February 2018, the estate of [Paul Zindel](/wiki/Paul_Zindel "Paul Zindel")
initiated a lawsuit in [United States District Court for the Central District
of
California](/wiki/United_States_District_Court_for_the_Central_District_of_California
"United States District Court for the Central District of California") against
director Guillermo del Toro and associate producer Daniel Kraus, alleging that
_The Shape of Water_ "brazenly copies the story, elements, characters, and
themes" of Zindel's 1969 work _[Let Me Hear You
Whisper](/wiki/Let_Me_Hear_You_Whisper_\(play\) "Let Me Hear You Whisper
\(play\)")_ , which depicts a cleaning lady bonding with a dolphin and
attempting to rescue it from a secret research laboratory's nefarious
uses.[44] The complaint spends more than a dozen pages detailing alleged
"overwhelming similarities" between the works.[45]

Del Toro denied the claim of the Zindel estate, saying that "I have never read
nor seen the play. I'd never heard of this play before making _The Shape of
Water,_ and none of my collaborators ever mentioned the play." Distributor
[Fox Searchlight](/wiki/Fox_Searchlight "Fox Searchlight") also denied the
claim and said that it would "vigorously defend" itself in court.[46]
